info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued March 30 at 11:50AM EDT until March 31 at 6:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...VERY WINDY CONDITIONS AND ONGOING WILDFIRES WILL YIELD CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS IN AND NEAR THE GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAINS THROUGH TONIGHT... .Strong southerly winds will ramp up quickly this afternoon and evening across the southwest mountains of western North Carolina ahead of an approaching cold front. While relative humidity values have briefly fallen into the 30s percent range around midday, the moisture will steadily increase under southerly flow through the late afternoon and evening hours. However, the very windy conditions will persist and worsen in areas of active fire suppression activity, and the onset of rain showers along the approaching front will be delayed until the early morning hours Thursday. This will provide a setup for critical fire weather conditions to develop this afternoon through most of tonight. ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM EDT THURSDAY FOR HIGH WINDS AND ACTIVE FIRE SUPPRESSION ACTIVITIES... The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a Red Flag Warning for high winds, which is in effect until 6 AM EDT Thursday. * AFFECTED AREA...Swain, Haywood, Graham, Northern Jackson and the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. * TIMING...Winds will increase through the afternoon hours, peak this evening and early overnight, then slowly wane through daybreak Thursday. * WINDS...South 20 to 30 mph with gusts of 50 to 60 mph, especially at elevations above 3500 feet. * HUMIDITY...As low as 38 percent early, but rising through the 40s and into the 50s tonight. * FUEL MOISTURE...Below 10 percent, with continued drying until the rain arrives later tonight. * IMPACTS...Outdoor fires may easily grow out of control under these conditions. Fires could quickly run long distances and pose a hazard to downwind communities.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of strong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior.
